Lets know middlewares better

In this post we will talk about middlewares in general- what they are and how to write them.
We will get our hands dirty by writing some examples first. In the later part we will use our knowledge to write middlewares for various frameworks like ReduxJS, ExpressJS and Django.

What are middlewares?

In general, middleware is some code you can put between some other code (hence the name). For example, when a server-side library receives a request, it will generate a response in return. Now you wish to “log” every request it receives. So you put a middleware in between the code of receiving a request and generating a response that will log the request.

But why would you put a middleware there? Can’t you just log the request “in-place”? Like this?

function getResponse(request) {
    ...
    log(request)
    ...
    return generateResponse(request)
}

Of course you can do that.
But what if you have so many of these functions that get the request and generate a response (for example each of them get the request from a different url path). So would you handle it like this? 

function getResponseForLoginRequest(request) {
    ...
    log(request)
    ...
    return generateResponseForLoginRequest(request.data.username, request.data.password)
}

function getResponseForLogoutRequest(request) {
    ...
    log(request)
    ...
    return generateResponseForLogoutRequest(request.data.username)
}

...
...
...

The best feature of middleware is that it’s composable in a chain. You can use multiple independent third-party middleware in a single project.
